questions.text: All of the following are true regarding superior mesenteric artery syndrome, except

options.label: A
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by the third part of the duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment

options.label: B
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery has a normal angle between 38°-65° about the duodenum

options.label: C
options.text: The strong procedure is corrective surgery in which the ligament of Treitz is divided

options.label: D
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is characterized by an angle less than 25° due to the loss of intervening mesenteric pad of fat

questions.correct_answer: A. Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by the third part of the duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by the third part of the duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is an unusual cause of small-bowel obstruction. Generally, the disorder presents as partial obstruction with postprandial nausea, vomiting, and weight loss Imaging studies suggest compression of the third portion of the duodenum as it passes between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. The diagnosis is confirmed by endoscopy (confirmation of extrinsic compression in the absence of intrinsic abnormality). CT angiography (CTA) and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) enable visualization of vascular compression of the duodenum and measurement of aortic and mesenteric distance: Normally, the aorta mesenteric angle and aortic mesenteric distance are 38–650 and 10–28 mm, respectively In SMA syndrome, both parameters are reduced, with values of <25° and <8 mm Patients most prone to this disorder are those with traumatic spinal cord injury, those with rapid weight loss combined with instrumentation, and those with anatomic variants, such as a short high ligament of Treitz or a low origin of the superior mesenteric artery. Treatment is generally duodenojejunostomy rather than manipulation of the vessels. Strong’s Procedure- Mobilize the DJ flexure and divide the ligament of Treitz Move the D3 away from the narrow aorta mesenteric angle No bowel anastomosis

Table:

#MANTRA Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) Syndrome Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) Syndrome is when the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum as it passes over this part of the intestine. It is also known as Wilkie's syndrome, cast syndrome, and arteriomesenteric duodenal ileus or compression . Three mechanical factors must be present for SMA Syndrome to occur: an abnormally narrow aortomesenteric angle, an abnormally highly fixed transverse duodenum, and an abnormal course of the mesenteric artery continuing inferiorly, anterior to the unyielding vertebral column. SMA Syndrome is most commonly seen in young, asthenic individuals, with women being more commonly affected than men. Rapid weight loss, supine immobilization, rapid height growth, scoliosis, and placement of a body cast are predisposing factors for SMA Syndrome. Symptoms of SMA Syndrome include profound nausea and vomiting, abdominal distention, weight loss, and postprandial epigastric pain, which varies from intermittent to constant depending on the severity of the duodenal obstruction. SMA Syndrome can be diagnosed through a barium upper gastrointestinal series or hypotonic biodemography, demonstrating abrupt or near-total cessation of barium flow from the duodenum to the jejunum. CT may also be helpful in certain instances. Conservative measures are tried initially and have been increasingly successful as definitive treatment for SMA Syndrome. The operative treatment of choice is duodenojejunostomy .

Because this sentinel node is the first node encountered by tumor cells as they metastasize to the regional nodal basin. It represents the tumor status of the entire nodal basin. First done in melanoma and subsequently adapted to breast cancer . If this sentinel node contains tumor cells, then other nodes in the basin may harbor metastasis, and complete nodal dissection should be performed. Regional nodal metastases are highly unlikely if the sentinel node is tumor-free and further nodal resection is not indicated. Tumor status of the axillary lymph nodes is one of the most important prognostic indicators for overall survival in breast cancer . The image in question shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy being done in a patient with carcinoma breast. The draining nodes are identified using either Methylene blue or Radio sulfur colloid labeled albumin or Fluorescein dye Lymph node basin Injection on the axillary side of the tumor. Blue dye (or radiocolloid) travels through the afferent lymphatic to the sentinel node.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female met with a road traffic accident. On examination, GCS 5/15, heart rate-160 bpm, BP 100/60 mm Hg, elevated JVP. The chest was tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds. Ecchymosis was present over the chest wall Abdomen was soft. The possible diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tension pneumothorax Most clinical signs of cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax are similar. Beck’s triad for pericardial tamponade (hypotension, distended neck veins, and, rarely, distant or muffled heart tones) is sometimes difficult to demonstrate clinically, especially amid a major resuscitation with concomitant hypovolemia. The most reliable signs of pericardial tamponade are a central venous pressure (CVP) elevated to 15 cm H 2 O or higher associated with hypotension and tachycardia. Pulsus paradoxus may also be present. As with any patient in shock, the physical findings can include dyspnea, agitation, restlessness, cyanosis, tachycardia, hypotension, and decreased mental activity. The cardinal signs of tension pneumothorax are tachycardia, jugular venous distension, and absent breath sounds on the ipsilateral side. These patients can also be dyspneic, agitated, restless, cyanotic, tachycardic, hypotensive, and confused. Absent breath sounds are essential to clinically differentiating these two conditions.

Highyeild:

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that can result in respiratory failure or cardiovascular collapse. It can be diagnosed clinically without the need for radiographic confirmation. The symptoms of tension pneumothorax include deviation of the trachea , unilaterally absent or diminished breath sounds, and cardiopulmonary compromise. If these symptoms are present, thoracic decompression should be rapidly performed with a large-bore needle or tube thoracostomy, depending on the availability of equipment and supplies.

Extraedge:

In addition to tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax requires tube thoracostomy to evacuate blood and reexpansion the lung. Severe pulmonary contusion may require aggressive mechanical ventilation with elevated levels of positive end-expiratory pressure. However, to avoid loss of positive end-expiratory pressure, the ventilator should not be repeatedly disconnected for suction or manual ventilation, as oxygenation will only improve with an uninterrupted circuit.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with hard painless testicular swelling. On investigation, AFP is 3080. No paraaortic or iliac nodes or mediastinal lymph nodes were found. USG shows uniform echotexture and small areas of necrosis. Surrounding structures are normal. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High inguinal orchidectomy The initial treatment of suspected testicular tumor is radical inguinal orchiectomy , which involves the removal of the testicle and spermatic cord at the level of the inguinal ring Second-line treatment is directed by tumor histology and lymph node staging. Further treatment may include regular surveillance, retroperitoneal radiation therapy, retroperitoneal lymph node dissection (RPLND), systemic chemotherapy, or a multimodal therapy approach.

Highyeild:

Testicular Tumours: Testicular cancer is an uncommon malignant neoplasm Most cases of primary testicular cancer are germ cell origin (95%); the remainder are predominantly stromal (Leydig cell) or sex cord (Sertoli cell) tumors. Any solid intratesticular mass is likely to represent a malignant germ cell tumor and is typically treated as such unless there is a strong suspicion to the contrary. Risk factors for testicular tumors include cryptorchidism, family history of testicular cancer, and intratubular germ cell neoplasia . Germ cell-derived testicular tumors can be broadly divided into seminoma and nonseminoma germ cell tumors (NSGCTs), approximately 50% for each. The majority of seminomas are classic (85%); the remainder is either anaplastic or spermatocyte seminoma. NSGCTs can be divided into histologic types: embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac or endodermal sinus tumors, choriocarcinoma, teratoma, and mixed germ cell tumors. Treatment : Initial treatment of suspected testicular tumor is radical inguinal orchiectomy , which involves removal of the testicle and spermatic cord at the level of the inguinal ring. Because of the characteristic and well-described lymph drainage of the testicle, there is no role for trans-scrotal biopsy or orchiectomy. If the intrascrotal tissue planes are violated during orchiectomy, the lymphatic drainage can be altered, affecting future treatment. After radical inguinal orchiectomy , the patient should undergo disease staging , including cross-sectional, contrast-enhanced imaging of the abdomen and pelvis, and chest imaging, either chest radiography in low-risk patients or cross-sectional chest imaging in patients with high-risk disease.

Table:

#MANTRA For seminoma stage IA and IB disease, treatment options in- include surveillance, radiotherapy to the regional (para-aortic) lymph nodes (20 Gy), and one or two cycles of carboplatin-based chemotherapy.59 For seminoma stage IIA and IIB, radiotherapy of the retroperitoneal lymph nodes is standard therapy; for stage IIC or III, platinum-based chemotherapy is standard therapy.59 For NSGCT stage I disease, the options include surveillance, primary RPLND, or cisplatin-based chemotherapy.59 For NSGCT stage IIA, either primary RPLND (in patients with normal levels of tumor markers) or three or four cycles of cisplatin-based chemotherapy is standard; for location IIB, three or four cycles of cisplatin-based chemotherapy is common, followed by RPLND or surveillance.59 For NSGCT Stage III, treatment consists of cisplatin-based chemotherapy, and when tumor markers normalize, perform RPLND.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon used 1.5 % glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. The nurse informs the surgeon of a 500 ml fluid deficit during the surgery. What is the next step to be done?

options.label: B
options.text: Change the fluid to normal saline

options.label: C
options.text: Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

options.label: D
options.text: Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.correct_answer: C. Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status Fluid deficit is the difference between the volume of distention fluid instilled into the uterine cavity and the volume of fluid removed through the outflow channel of the hysteroscope, plus fluid collected from the drapes or inadvertently lost in drapes and surrounding area of the operative table. The deficit closely represents the amount of fluid that may have been absorbed into the patient’s vasculature. A fluid deficit of more than 1000 ml should be used as a threshold to define fluid overload when using hypotonic solutions (glycine 1.5%, sorbitol 3%) in healthy women of reproductive age. A fluid deficit of 2500 ml should be used as a threshold to define fluid overload when using isotonic solutions (Normal saline) in healthy women of reproductive age. Surgery is immediately stopped upon reaching these limits. Asymptomatic hypervolemia can be managed by fluid restriction with or without diuretics. The patient should be observed for symptoms of hyponatremia, and continued electrolyte monitoring should be done.

questions.text: Packed RBC is transfused within how much time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Finish within 4 hours The transfusion rate depends on the patient's clinical condition and transfused component. Most patients not in congestive heart failure or danger of fluid overload tolerate the transfusion of one unit of red cells in 1–2 hours. To minimize the severity of a transfusion reaction or the amount of blood hemolyzed if this is going to occur, the first 25–50 mL of the component should be transfused slowly, and the patient should be If no adverse reaction occurs, the rate can be increased. The transfusion should be completed in less than 4 hours because of the dangers of bacterial proliferation , which may occur as the blood warms to room temperature.

questions.text: Renal calculi most resistant to shockwave lithotripsy is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystine Cystine and brushite stones are most resistant to ESWL, followed by calcium oxalate monohydrate. The descending order of resistance for other stones are as follows Cystine and Brushite → Ca oxalate monohydrate → struvite → Ca oxalate dihydrate → uric acid

Highyeild:

EXTRACORPOREAL SHOCKWAVE LITHOTRIPSY (ESWL, ESL) : This is a non-invasive method of treating urinary tract stones by generating shockwaves outside the body which are focused on the stones. It was first used on humans in Germany in 1980. Different shock wave generation methods include spark gap, electromagnetic, piezoelectric, and micro-expulsive. Shockwaves generated using the spark-gap method must be coordinated with the patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) to prevent cardiac arrhythmias. Stones can be localized for treatment using either fluoroscopy or USS. This is the standard form of treatment for renal calculi, and stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. More than one treatment session may be needed to treat the stone, especially if it is sizeable entirely. Prophylactic antibiotics are used to prevent infection, as bacteria often colonize stones. Cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. In addition to infection, ESWL may result in haematuria, parenchymal bleeding, and even perirenal hematoma. A collection of stone fragments in a ureter after ESWL for a significant renal stone is given the German name of steinstrasse (‘street of stones’). Contraindications to ESWL are obese, pregnant, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C & D: All other stones are comparatively less resistant to ESWL than Cystine stones.

Extraedge:

The efficacy of SWL reduces with an increasing number of stones and volume of stone burden. Steinstrasse is a German word meaning ‘ street of stones ’. It describes a row of closely gathered stone fragments that line the distal end of the ureter These stones are usually asymptomatic and pass spontaneously ; however, they may cause obstruction, requiring surgical intervention.

questions.explanation:

Oncogenes implicated in thyroid cancer RAS - PTC, FTC, Hurthle cell carcinoma RET - PTC, Medullary Thyroid carcinoma MET - PTC (75%), FTC (25%) P53 - poorly differentiated PTC, FTC, Anaplastic Ca (tumor suppressor gene) BRAF - PTC, Tall cell, poorly differentiated cancer, anaplastic cancer PTEN - Follicular adenoma and carcinoma (tumor suppressor gene)

Highyeild:

Papillary Carcinoma of Thyroid Papillary Carcinoma of Thyroid is the most common type of thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, accounting for 80% of cases. It is most commonly found in women aged 30-40 and is the most common thyroid cancer in children and individuals exposed to external radiation. Grossly, the tumor is hard and whitish with macroscopic calcification, necrosis, or cystic changes. It is often multifocal on microscopic examination and is associated with an increased risk of cervical nodal metastases. Papillary Carcinoma of the Thyroid is rarely encapsulated and may invade adjacent structures, although this is rare. Other variants, such as tall cells, insular, and poorly differentiated types, account for about 1% and are associated with a worse prognosis. papillary projections, orphan Annie eye nuclei, and psammoma bodies characterize Papillary Carcinoma of the Thyroid. The diagnosis is based on nuclear characteristics, even without papillary structures. Most patients present with a slow-growing, painless mass in the neck, and dysphagia, dyspnea, and dysphonia are associated with locally advanced invasive disease. Lymph node metastases are common, especially in children and young adults, and maybe the presenting complaint. Diagnosis is established by fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the thyroid mass or lymph node. Once diagnosed, a complete neck ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for lymph node metastases. Treatment involves total or near-total thyroidectomy , removing enlarged central neck nodes during surgery. Biopsy-proven lymph node metastases in the lateral neck are managed with modified radical neck dissection. Papillary Carcinoma of the Thyroid has an excellent prognosis, with a >95% 10-year survival rate.

Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm An abdominal aortic aneurysm is by far the most common type of large-vessel aneurysm and is found in 2% of the population at autopsy; 95% have associated atheromatous degeneration and 95% occur below the renal arteries Gender differences in a variety of factors have led some to advocate for consideration of aneurysm repair at a smaller size in women. It has been observed that the average size of the “normal” aorta tends to be slightly smaller in women.” Most common site of AAA- Infrarenal aorta Most common site of rupture is retroperitoneum, and the most common site of rupture into GIT is the 4th part of the Triad of rupture of AAA (seen in around 25% cases) Sudden onset mid-abdominal or flank pain Sudden onset shock Pulsatile abdominal mass Investigation of choice—CT (for diagnosing and for planning surgery) Drugs found to help reduce the risk of rupture—NSAIDs and tetracycline Atypical aneurysm regardless of their size needs surgical intervention (dissecting aneurysm, mycotic aneurysm, and pseudoaneurysm) Types : Asymptomatic AAA : An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (Figure 61.39) in an otherwise ft patient should be considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter, measured by ultrasonography in the anteroposterior plane Investigations: CT Scan (Morphology best assessed) Treatment: Open or Endovascular aneurysm repair Ruptured AAA : Abdominal aortic aneurysms can rupture anteriorly into the peritoneal cavity (20%) or posterolaterally into the retroperitoneal space (80%). Investigations : CT Scan Management : Early diagnosis (abdominal/back pain, pulsatile mass, shock) Immediate resuscitation (oxygen, intravenous replacement therapy, central line) Maintain systolic pressure, but not >100 mmHg Urinary catheter Cross-match blood Rapid transfer to the operating room Treatment : Endovascular Repair Symptomatic AAA: These patients are most commonly present with abdominal and back pain but the aneurysm is not ruptured on a CT scan. Pain may also occur in the thigh and groin because of nerve compression. Gastrointestinal, urinary, and venous symptoms can also be caused by pressure from an abdominal aneurysm Treatment: Surgery should be done as soon as possible. Postoperative Complications: Cardiac (ischemia and infarction) and respiratory (atelectasis and lower lobe consolidation) complications are more common after open repair Endoleak, graft migration, metal strut fracture, and graft limb occlusion are more common after EVAR Classification of endoleaks following endovascular aneurysm repair. Type of endoleak Definition Type I Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to an ineffective seal at the proximal (la) or distal (lb) end of the stent-graft Type II Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to retrograde flow of blood from aortic collaterals, e.g., IMA, lumbar arteries Type III Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to structural failure of the stent-graft as a result of component disconnection (Illa) or stent fabric tear (IIIb) Type IV Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to stent-graft fabric porosity Type V Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac without evidence of types I-IV endoleak

Extraedge:

Most abdominal aortic aneurysms remain asymptomatic until rupture occurs; the risk of fracture increases with the increasing size (diameter) of the aneurysm. A UK national screening program for abdominal aortic aneurysms commenced in 2009, offering an ultrasonography scan to men in their 65th year. In recent years, there has been much discussion regarding the optimal way to treat an abdominal aortic aneurysm with open surgical repair and endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR), having vocal advocates in the scientific literature.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the boundaries of the triangle of doom?

options.label: A
options.text: Medially vas deferens, laterally gonadal vessel, posteriorly peritoneum

options.label: B
options.text: Laterally vas deferens, medially gonadal vessel, inferiorly peritoneum

options.label: C
options.text: Laterally medial umbilical ligament, medially gonadal vessel, Lateral inferior peritoneum

options.label: D
options.text: Laterally gonadal vessels and medially lateral umbilical ligament, inferiorly peritoneum

questions.correct_answer: A. Medially vas deferens, laterally gonadal vessel, posteriorly peritoneum

The gonadal vessels and the iliac vain form a triangle with its apex upward; in the area of the iliac vessels; this anatomical area, called “triangle of doom,” as well as the so-called “triangle of pain,” located between the anterior superior iliac spine and the gonadal vessels, warrants particular attention Familiarity with these two regions is crucial during laparoscopic inguinal hernioplasty because they are areas with high potential for severe complications such as trans operative vascular lesions or painful postoperative sequelae The triangle of doom Borders Medially: By the vas deferens Laterally : By the vessels of the spermatic cord Inferiorly : Peritoneal fold Contents: The external iliac vessels Deep circumflex iliac vein Femoral nerve Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve. The triangle of pain Borders Inferolaterally : Ilio-pubic tract Superomedially : Gonadal vessels Contents : The lateral femoral cutaneous Femoral branch of the genitofemoral Femoral nerves. The circle of death is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
